meanings.definition: Call on (a deity or spirit) in prayer, as a witness, or for inspiration.
meanings.sent1: During the ceremony, the priest will invoke the blessings of the gods.
meanings.sent2: She decided to invoke the guidance of her ancestors during this difficult time.
meanings.sent3: The young girl would often playfully invoke the help of imaginary fairies in her games.
meanings.sent4: The artist's painting seemed to invoke the tranquility of a serene forest.
meanings.sent5: The old man's words were so powerful, they seemed to invoke a sense of peace in everyone around him.

meanings.definition: Cite or appeal to (someone or something) as an authority for an action or in support of an argument.
meanings.sent1: The lawyer will invoke the testimony of the witness to prove his case.
meanings.sent2: In his essay, he chose to invoke the words of a famous philosopher to strengthen his argument.
meanings.sent3: The student jokingly tried to invoke the authority of his pet dog to get out of doing homework.
meanings.sent4: Her speech managed to invoke the wisdom of past leaders to inspire the audience.
meanings.sent5: The politician's words were carefully crafted to invoke a sense of unity among the citizens.

meanings.definition: Summon (a law or precedent) in support of one's case.
meanings.sent1: The attorney will invoke the legal precedent to defend his client in court.
meanings.sent2: During the debate, the debater tried to invoke a specific law to strengthen his argument.
meanings.sent3: The children playfully decided to invoke the 'no dessert before dinner' rule to avoid eating vegetables.
meanings.sent4: The author's novel seemed to invoke the spirit of classic literature in a modern setting.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's words were able to invoke a sense of responsibility in the students to study harder.
